overwrite.h: Implicitly overwrites exported documentation file if it exists already.

json.h: Selected metadata is returned as json dictionary

keys.h: Return only keys from metadata dictionary

values.h: Return only values from metadata dictionary

metadata.in: KEY can be provided to get only selected key(s) from metadata dictionary. If KEY is not provided then all keys from metadata dictionary are selected.

only.h: Print only arguments Cheat Sheet syntax and exit.

syntax.h: Print arguments Cheat Sheet syntax and exit.

_path_etc_.h: Print program configuration path and exit.

_query_.h: Load program's arguments from a json file with optional parameterized values.
_query_.in: query argument allows to execute safe command-line arguments query on the program. Command-line arguments are collected through a JSON file. The JSON file has two attributes 'command' and 'params'. 'command' accepts a list of command-line arguments with values where each value may be replaced with a question mark. 'params' accepts a list of values. The number of values in 'params' must match the number of question marks in 'command'. 'command' arguments are only parsed as arguments and 'params' are only parsed as argument values. It allows a safe way to pass values collected from a third party program like a web application to the command-line program. All errors are returned as a json dump for better communication with third party program.(see Nargs developer documentation)

depth.h: Provide the printing depth of nested arguments.
depth.in: If LEVEL == -1 then all nested arguments are printed. If LEVEL == 0 then only selected argument is printed. If LEVEL > 0 then the bigger the LEVEL number is, the bigger the children nesting level is if any children are available.

flags.h: Print flag set if any for all arguments available on the terminal.

from.h: This option allows to start printing usage from a parent.
from.in: If LEVEL == -1 then selected argument is the root argument. If LEVEL == 0 then selected argument is the current argument. If LEVEL > 0 then one argument parent is selected and the bigger the LEVEL number is, the older the selected parent is unless parent's limit is reached. Argument's parent's limit is the oldest parent also called the root argument.

_usage_.in: LEVEL is an integer >= 0. LEVEL number describes the number of nested node levels to print. LEVEL number is relative to current argument node level. If LEVEL == 0 then all nested node levels are printed. If LEVEL == 1 then only current argument is printed. If LEVEL > 1 current argument's node levels are printed and LEVEL sets the depth of node levels nesting.

compile.in: Two modes are available. FAT or SLIM. FAT compile the whole solution. SLIM only compile with the linked references.

params.in: Add params for the file compiled with run command

link.in: Gives Keywords to help findind the reference files for linking

slim.in: select reference to add to the project with keywords using --link parameters or manually edit the file in the _runtime/project_name/conf/project_name.conf file.

ex:
msbuild --csc PROJECT_NAME --run --params thisisparam --slim
msbuild --csc PROJECT_NAME --run --params thisisparam --exe
msbuild --csc PROJECT_NAME --run --params thisisparam --fat
csc.in: This command allow quick build for aside development, on selected files to link with csc.exe compiler. Pick a project name to start. It is going to create a new project in _runtime folder with a main and a reference file, that is going to have all the solution files listed. Then you need to compile with --slim or --fat. --fat select all the referenced files. --slim only run files that are not commented in the reference file. You can comment these references manaually or you enable them with --link parameter. for --slim and --fat an exe file is created and is runned. --run only run the executable that have been created. For --fat, --slim, and --run you can select the --params that is going to send parameters to the executable created. This commands create a standalone cli program by extracting a subset of the current solution.

add.in: add files to csproj if needed.

clean.in: remove files to csproj if needed.

update.in: delete and add files to csproj if needed.

db.in: wrapper access to entity db. If no cmd is given help is displayed.

path_csproj.in: main path where .csproj is located, if not given current path is selected

include.in: given relative paths, push only these paths to the project, instead of the whole project.

publish.in: if you add the --deploy argument then deploy will be executed only if the publish build is new, or webconfig has been modified or pre-deploy scripts has been executed

profile.in: profiles are 'debug, dev, proxy, release, test

ex:
mstools -p proxy --publish -r --any
mstools --deploy -p proxy --push '"web.config"'
(deprecated for ftp only) mstools -p mydev --deploy --exclude app scripts
(deprecated for ftp only) mstools -p mydev --deploy --include App/app/divisions --exclude scripts
(deprecated for ftp only) mstools -p mydev --publish -r any --deploy --exclude app scripts App_Data Content EmailTemplates bin\roslyn fonts Properties Views
mstools -p prod --publish -r fullstack --pre-deploy _scripts\migration_copy_sql.py --zip-release
mstools --run --main mydebug --params thisisparam --slim
mstools --run --main mydebug --params thisisparam --exe
mstools --run --main mydebug --params thisisparam --fat
mstools --run --main mydebug --slim --quiet

# csc create a project in _runtime folder
# it is for quick test on files that don't need to compile the whole solution.
# fat use all the assemblies to compile you project
mstools --csc mydebug --fat
# run allow to run your compiled file once build
mstools --csc mydebug --run
# slim use only the assemblies selected with the keywords from link argument
mstools --csc mydebug --slim --link mimetypes mydebug.cs system.net.http.dll datahelpers newtonsoft web.http.dll

metadata.description: wrapper for several microsoft tools, like msbuild.exe csc.exe msdeploy.exe
metadata.name: mstools
